history.content: If you want to focus on getting better at linear algebra and its applications, then going through Math 54/Math 110 will be more than enough. The EE16A/B series, as many students have found, doesn't do the best job at teaching linear algebra and diffeqs.

If you want to focus on getting better at linear algebra and its applications, then going through Math 54/Math 110/EECS 127 will be more than enough. The EE16A/B series, as many students have found, doesn't do the best job at teaching linear algebra and diffeqs.

children.subject: Second m54 or m110. Take 54 if it’s your math class in a while.

(This isn't really what OP asked about, but this is just my take on transitioning from Math 110 to EECS 127)

I would argue that going from Math 110 to EECS 127 is actually quite difficult. Both teach linear algebra in a different manner. And things like SVD, pseudoinverse, PCA, least squares, linear programs, controllability, etc. isn't really taught in Math 110, whereas EECS 127 blazes past them in the first half of the course (b/c it assumes you already know it from EECS 16B).

But also, this is definitely only one side of Math 110, and it can have many benefits depending on what else you end up doing. Like I definitely think 110 helps give a more solid grasp on fundamental linear algebra topics, but it's also presented in a much more classical 'mathy' sense than the EECS series, and I personally haven't used it that much as a CS major. Whereas, the controls and optimization side of EECS is something I find more applicable.

Source: I took EECS 16A/Math 110/EECS 127, did well on the first two, but poor on 127. Now that I have taken 16B though, it definitely makes 127 seem 10x easier since I don't have to catch up on the initial linear algebra part.

history.content:
I finished my lower divs in my first year (I am graduating) and have not taken any math related classes since -- something I regret. 

I'll be working somewhere where a strong math background, particularly regarding linalg and probability, will be useful. I'm wondering if it's worth self-studying 16ab again this summer to get up to par with the math required for engineering contexts since I pretty much forgot everything I learned, or if something like math 110 would be more useful.

Thanks!
history.subject: is the 16ab series a good primer on linear algebra?
